title: In contemplation of divorce, is there a way to make post-nuptial agreement stating no one owes and wont owe no one nothing?
question: In contemplation of divorce, is there a way to make a sworn notarized affidavit or some kind of post-nuptial agreement (if thats what its called) between the parties, where they state that from the separation date and on, parties don't owe each other nothing, will never claim anything in the future by consensually and voluntarily signing this document? are there examples or templates of such documents? Thank you very much.
question_tags: Divorce,Uncontested divorce,No-fault divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Child support,Divorce and bankruptcy,Child custody,Custody agreement and child custody,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Child support and custody,Family law
answers:
i agree with all of the attorneys cogent answers. With that said, I think you should know that after the date of your separation, all property and debts acquired/incurred thereafter are the separate property and obligations of the respective parties. That includes income and retirement contributions. Also, if one party remains in the family residence for their exclusive use, the other party has a credit to the extent of the fair rental value of the property, and if one party post-separation pays down the principal on the mortgage from post-separation earnings, then that party has a claim to the extent of a separate property interest in the community asset.
You do not need an interim agreement post-separation to necessarily address these issues pending the resolution of a divorce proceeding.
Needless to say, these issues are complicated and this information is for informational purposes only, and is not intended as legal advice upon which you should rely or as a basis for the formation of an attorney-client relationship. Good luck.

You could enter an agreement after marriage and before a divorce proceeding is filed, as you said, a post-nuptial agreement. However, this a developing area of the law, and you and your spouse should proceed carefully to maximize the chances for its enforceability, and should take steps such as, each of you having counsel, making a full disclosure of material information about your assets, debts, and all other claims and rights which are being negotiated, having consideration or an exchange of value if there are any rights or claims waived, and provide each other sufficient time to review the agreement. Entering into an agreement after you file for divorce, is a much more settled area of the law; this type of agreement is commonly called a Marital Settlement Agreement. You and your spouse could be unrepresented and enter into an agreement as you described. However, you will still to have comply with disclosure requirements and depending on what you are agreeing on, there may be requirements as to what you have to include in the agreement (i.e. child support and custody agreement require certain language to be included in the agreement or the agreement may be rejected by the court).

It can be done (it'd be a "settlement agreement") , but there's some fairly specific and fairly complicated requirements to make it be an enforceable document, and some agreements (like "no child support") CANNOT be done as permanent enforceable agreements. This is NOT a do-it-yourself job, if you and your spouse have any significant property or income.

There is such a thing. It's called either a marital settlement agreement or a stipulated judgment. You can attach the stipulated judgment to your final judgment paperwork. If both you and your spouse proceed in pro per (are not represented by counsel) the agreement will need to be signed and notarized
It's called a settlement agreement, and it's rarely the kind of thing you want to attempt on a do it yourself basis.
